comment._content: I don't have a garden to produce vegetables for canning, but I do can chicken stock or beef stock. Home canning is not as widespread as it used to be, but it's still common enough that my local large drugstore carries canning supplies.

comment.author: 23015285@N04
comment._content: My mom and dad used to stay up very late at night canning food from our garden.  This was after a full days work.  They used an old pressure cooker to seal the jars.  The results were delicious.

comment.author: 87737023@N00
comment._content: This looks like a normal stack of preserves  from my Georgia Grand parents basement shelves in the 1950's (but they had more Peaches and watermelon)

comment.author: 10213344@N07
comment._content: I see turnip Greens, beans, peeled and cut up potatoes, the red things look like canned radishes, but never heard of that before? I see beets, green shelled peas, also looks like peeled bellpepper. I guess the canned everything. Its much healthier and no salt to can. If you can obtain fresh veggies and you can freeze some of them, canning is great way to go.

comment.author: 23312570@N02
comment._content: Mindful of the harvest from a Victory Garden I watched my mother work on in Forest Grove, OR, in 1944.

comment.author: 22281867@N04
comment._content: I still can my own jams and preserves.  I also do pickles and relishes occasionally. I grew up watching and helping my mom can fruits and vegetables.  My dad also canned, he did salsas and  relishes.

comment.author: 31580040@N04
comment._content: When I used to do this it was called "bottling", in Kilner jars.  If bottling is called canning in America then that answers my question of how everyone soldered the cand shut and didn't poison themselves.

comment.author: 30817808@N00
comment._content: Bottling and/or preserving this process is called in NZ.

comment.author: 31580040@N04
comment._content:
Mikescott, in the UK we use bottling for keeping food intact, as in these jars.  Preserving is used for jams and chutneys.  And then there's pickling, where you soak the food in brine for 3 0r 4 days and then pack it in vinegar.

The term preserving would work for all three methods, so I don't know why we split them up like this.

comment.author: 9691753@N02
comment._content: And I'm ready for dinner.  My mom used to can.  We had a fairly large garden.  This just looks so natural and like "real food." lol   Now I try to buy organics when I can afford it to get something closer to real food.  I still can't find a tomato that tastes like a fresh tomato out of the garden 50 years ago, though.mmmm  I wish I had one of those, just biting into it with the juice dripping down my face.  I was 10. Juice dripping down your face is cute when you are 10 :D

comment._content: Those are Kilner jars aren't they? A letter 'K' is visible on the box below. My mother (and my grandmother) used to preserve a whole range of fruit and vegetables from the garden.
